@graph.name: PilgrimIRL
@graph.description: Comprehensive database of Ireland's sacred Christian heritage including monastic sites, pilgrimage routes, holy wells, and Irish saints.

@graph.name: Ireland Sacred Sites Database
@graph.description: Comprehensive database of 817+ sacred Christian sites across all 32 counties of Ireland, including monasteries, holy wells, high crosses, and pilgrimage routes.

@graph.name: Sacred Site Types in Ireland

item.name: Monastic Sites
item.description: Ancient Irish monasteries, abbeys, priories, and friaries from the early Christian and medieval periods

item.name: Pilgrimage Routes
item.description: Sacred walking paths and traditional pilgrimage routes across Ireland

item.name: Christian Sites
item.description: Holy wells, high crosses, mass rocks, round towers, and other Christian heritage sites

item.name: Irish Saints
item.description: 101 Irish saints and their associated sacred sites across Ireland

@graph.name: Notable Irish Saints
@graph.description: Major patron saints of Ireland documented on PilgrimIRL

item.name: Saint Patrick
item.description: Patron saint of Ireland, 5th century missionary who converted Ireland to Christianity

item.name: Saint Brigid of Kildare
item.description: Female patron saint of Ireland, founder of Kildare monastery

item.name: Saint Colmcille
item.description: Founder of Iona monastery, one of the Twelve Apostles of Ireland

item.name: Saint Kevin of Glendalough
item.description: Founder of Glendalough monastic settlement in County Wicklow

item.name: Saint Brendan the Navigator
item.description: Early Irish monastic saint known for legendary voyage to the Isle of the Blessed

item.name: Glendalough
item.description: Early medieval monastic settlement founded by St. Kevin in the 6th century

item.name: Clonmacnoise
item.description: Major monastic site on the River Shannon, founded by St. Ciarán in 544 AD

item.name: Skellig Michael
item.description: UNESCO World Heritage Site, remote island monastery off the coast of Kerry

item.name: Rock of Cashel
item.description: Historic site featuring a round tower, Romanesque chapel, and Gothic cathedral

@graph.name: Frequently Asked Questions about Irish Sacred Sites

mainEntity.name: What is the oldest monastery in Ireland?

acceptedAnswer.text: Armagh, founded by St. Patrick around 445 AD, is traditionally considered the oldest monastic foundation in Ireland. However, many early Christian sites like Ardmore (founded by St. Declan) may predate Patrick's arrival.

mainEntity.name: What are the most famous pilgrimage sites in Ireland?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most famous Irish pilgrimage sites include Croagh Patrick in County Mayo, Lough Derg in County Donegal, Knock Shrine in County Mayo, and Glendalough in County Wicklow.

mainEntity.name: How many holy wells are there in Ireland?

acceptedAnswer.text: Ireland has over 3,000 documented holy wells, making it one of the highest concentrations of sacred water sites in Europe. These wells are often associated with local saints and traditional healing practices.

mainEntity.name: Who are the patron saints of Ireland?

acceptedAnswer.text: The three patron saints of Ireland are St. Patrick (March 17), St. Brigid of Kildare (February 1), and St. Columba/Colmcille (June 9). St. Patrick is the primary patron saint.

mainEntity.name: What is a round tower in Ireland?

acceptedAnswer.text: Round towers (cloigtheach in Irish) are tall, slender stone towers built at early medieval monastic sites in Ireland between the 9th and 12th centuries. They served as bell towers, landmarks, and places of refuge during Viking raids. About 65 survive in varying conditions across Ireland.
